answers.answer: That's excellent that you are seeing such a dip in your numbers through natural means.  Keep up your hard and good work to see how far you can reverse that number.  I don't know if you'll get to numbers below the guideline---  but you are doing the best thing for yourself by incorporating lifestyle changes right now.  I think you can only do so much with that but you'll have to wait and see HOW much of an effect this new healthy regime has.   Is your doctor thrilled?  What do they say the next step is.  Since you are new to type 2 diabetes, here is a link to many articles here that at be of interest to you.  Lots of diabetes articles in the archive with pages to scroll through.http://www.medhelp.org/diabetes?section=articles  Ifound several I thought were really helpful.  Hey, stay in touch and let me know how you are doing.  I find you very inspiring!  good luck

It takes a while for your bs to go down to normal range from that high of a number. Plus the standard finger prick tests only measure the immediate amount of bs in that area. A1c test measurements measure the entire bodys bs levels over a 2-3 month span.

Hi,a reduction from 175 to 140 is good progress.140 fasting still puts you very much in diabetic territory, as ideally fasting will be < 95.  2 hours post eating will be < 120.Adding of an insulin sensitising medication such as metformin/ glucophage may be next step.Keep up your great efforts. As you are discovering eating lower carb is very beneficial to management.  When eating low carb you may need to add more protein and healthy fats for energy.  I see you are vegetarian.  Do you still take dairy?  butter / ghee/ cream can all be part of your diet if you do.  Nuts can also be good. Olive, coconut and nut oils can be good.  Use your blood sugar meter to monitor the effects of various foods on your blood sugar and then you can use this to adjust your diet.
